title: Synthetic Recap
body:
BOSTON – On a night where offense was a premium and legends were forged in grit, the Boston Celtics did not win this 1998 battle with a team effort. They won because Antoine Walker decided he would not be denied.

In a brutal, low-scoring affair that finished 92-85 in favor of the Celtics, Walker authored a performance for the ages, pouring in a game-high 41 points against the Chicago Bulls. While the final score indicates a team victory, this was a one-man tour de force, a symphony of scoring in a game otherwise defined by defensive dissonance.

The Celtics, as a unit, struggled from the field. Their collective 36.5% shooting was a testament to the Bulls' typically ferocious defense. Yet, Walker operated on a different plane. He was the lone consistent threat, slicing to the rim and hitting from the perimeter with a volume and efficiency that left the Bulls scrambling for answers. His 41 points stood in stark contrast to the rest of the game's flow, a beacon of individual brilliance on a night of collective offensive struggle.

Michael Jordan, as expected, led Chicago with 28 points, but even his greatness was muted by the sheer force of Walker’s will. The Celtics’ victory was not pretty, but it was historic. It was a testament to one player’s transcendent ability to seize a game and carry his team, against all odds and offensive woes, to a hard-fought triumph on the parquet floor. On this night, the Garden celebrated not just a win, but a legendary scoring feat from its young star.
